First of all I mean no offense and am truly sorry if I come off in a way that makes you think I do. Certain people have brought an air of arrogance and hostility to this board that I want no part of.
 
 Anyway...
 I fail to see the correlation between the method and circumstances in which a woman becomes pregnant and the status of the child as a human being. And in terms of the length that a woman has been pregnant I think is also irrelevant. At what point does the mass of flesh become human? When is that magical moment in which it goes from nothing more than what I would scrape from the inside of my cheek to a human being with a personality, rights, and a place in humanity? I don't think that we as human beings can make that distinction, and the fact that we don't know takes the issue out of our moral and ethical territory, we can not make a decision when we don't have the knowledge to which the entire issue hinges upon.
 
 I, personally, believe that there is no "moment", no second of transfiguration in which at 8:32 the being is no more than a clump of cells and upon the arrival of 8:33 we have an inexplicably new being; a human like ourselves. 
 
 I say that until we can state this moment, this second of the induction into the human race, we are not in the moral position to make a choice. Quite obviously we will never reach this point, and so to be frank, I believe that the mother's only "choice" is whether to raise the child herself or to hand it over to one of the millions of couples who want desperately to have and raise the inconveniant clump of cells as their own.

 RU 486 AND PROSTAGLANDIN:
 The French-developed "abortion pill" is a powerful anti-hormone (steroid) called mifepristone that interrupts the natural life process by inhibiting production of the progesterone necessary to prepare the uterine wall to support the pregnancy. As a result, the tiny developing baby literally starves to death as the nutrient lining of the womb sloughs off, and muscular contractions cause the dead baby to be expelled from the uterus. It is used to induce abortions between the fifth to ninth weeks of pregnancy. Women first take RU486 alone. Within 48 hours, only three percent have a completed abortion. The remainder of the women, ninety-seven percent, must take a second powerful drug, a prostaglandin. In approximately five to ten percent of the women who use the RU486 abortion method, the drugs fail to kill the developing baby and the women usually have follow-up surgical abortions. RU486 can cause severe disabilities in babies who survive the abortion, can injure and possibly kill women, and could harm a woman's subsequent offspring. Preliminary findings of the first independent studies reveal serious under- reporting of the abortion technique's adverse side effects. With RU486, a mother will more directly participate in ending the life of her unborn child, and verify that she has passed the "uterine content" that is her dead baby. Nearly half of the French women polled report that they find this verification process disturbing.

I'm not going to really go into the abortion debate right now, since I'm still trying to make up my own mind about it. The comments here have been insightful, tho, so thanks, everyone :)
 
 I would, however, like to make a note about the morning after pill. The morning after pill and RU-486 are two totally different things. The latter is an early stage pregnancy abortion pill which is good for the first 9 weeks of pregnancy. While I'm not sure of the exact mechanics of how it acts, it mimics a natural miscarriage. 
 
 The "morning after" pill, is only good for 3 to 5 days after intercourse. Basically, it is series of pills, containing a coctail of concentrated birth control hormones. It can act to prevent or delay ovulation. It can also slow the transport of sperm. prevents conception which often occurs several hours or even days after intercourse (sperm can "live" inside you for three days or more!). The pill may also create an autoimmune response that causes the white blood cells to attack the sperm as foreign bodies. So, In this respect, they act pretty much like normal birth control. As with birth control, if an embryo has already implanted the pills have no effect.
 
 The controversy over this pill comes from the fact that in the case that the pills are taken too late and conception has already occurred, the pills can prevent implantation of the embryo. There is some argument as to the degree of their effectiveness in preventing implantaion. Some feel that even one fertilized embryo that is rejected is one too many. Others argue that even in normal women using no contraception embryos often fail to implant. This is why it often takes several months for a couple tryin for a baby to concieve. (I personally believe that the number of attempts it takes to concieve is inversely proportional to how hard you're trying for a baby *lol*) They add that since most pregancies are stopped before conception, the rate or failed implantations is close to that for women under normal conditaions.
 
 The question, I guess, is whether the zygote is merely a formless ball of undifferentiated cells, or a potential human being in the making. Its a difficult one, and as yet I have not been able to come to any descision. I would, however, love to hear your thoughts on it.

Also, the holocaust had the same logic. The Nazis said "If you don't like it, don't do it". Should thus allow the Nazis to slaughter Catholics, Jews, homosexuals and Slavs? I think not!"
 
 That's ridiculous. We're still debating over whether or not the fetus can be considered a human being. (I have yet to arrive at an opinion on that score) Jews and homosexuals and Slavs are people, (I don't see any debate professing otherwise). They were seperate and independent from the womb and were capable of surviving without someone else's uterus at the point in which they were murdered. Besides, one of the most horrifying aspects of the holocaust were the reasons why those things were done. Mass genocide is different from abortion. However, I can see your point with the comparison to murder. I need to think about that one.
 
 "Murder" (by my definition, anyway,) is the taking of another's life... Half the horror of which is in the pain and agony in which the victim dies. Having your exoskeleton crushed and your intestined ruptured isn't painful? Being shot in the stomach mid-flight, then plummeting towards the earth to shatter your skull on the pavement isn't painful? Having sharp metal teeth clamp shut on your body while you're trying to fetch a bit of cheese isn't painful? 
 
 Partial birth abortions are disgusting, and the manner in which they perform it is chilling to the core, and so I think they should continue looking for another way to do it. A way that doesn't torture the fetus. Abortion itself, i do not have a problem with, although I have mixed emotions on the topic of partial birth abortions....
 
 Alright, I'll finish posting later. I've lost my train of thought and I'm hungry.

PBA: partial-birth abortion. Sorry about that. :D 
 
 I in no way intended to insult you. I HAVE been trying to speak to someone like yourself for a long time.

That's ridiculous. We're still debating over whether or not the fetus can be considered a human being. (I have yet to arrive at an opinion on that score)

 
 Define "human being". 
 
 
Jews and homosexuals and Slavs are people, (I don't see any debate professing otherwise). They were seperate and independent from the womb and were capable of surviving without someone else's uterus at the point in which they were murdered.

 
 So your definition of "human being" is someone who has already been born? Many fetuses are capable of surviving separate from there mother. In that case, by your definition, they are human beings.
 
 
Besides, one of the most horrifying aspects of the holocaust were the reasons why those things were done. Mass genocide is different from abortion.

 
 How is mass genocide different from abortion? We are killing babies simply because they are a "nuisance". (Especially "problem" babies with disabilities.)
 
 genocide: he deliberate and systematic destruction of a racial, political, or cultural group
 
 race:a class or kind of people unified by community of interests, habits, or characteristics
 
 Abortion is mass genocide.
I guess that makes capitol punishment genocide.

Criminals do not fall into the category of a racial, political, or cultural group. Therefore, if you use the definition already on the board, capital punishment is not genocide.
 
 Also, capital punishment is not systematically destroying any group of people. We use capital punishment only when a person is found guilty by jury and it is determined that the facts necessitate it.

Criminals do not fall into the category of a racial, political, or cultural group.
 
 
 It falls into the vague 'race' group since they share the characteristic that they have committed a crime.
I don't believe in capital punishment, but capitol punishment is not genocide.

punk sushi, 
 
 have you seen these pictures? Fallingupwards posted them earlier in the thread, and maybe you missed them.http://www.survivors.la/abortionpics.html

It falls into the vague 'race' group since they share the characteristic that they have committed a crime.
 
 Is having committed a crime really a characteristic?

[QUOTE=punk_sushi]Maybe I'm going to be the only adamant pro-choice member on this forum. 
 
 Oh, I am completely pro-choice.
 I believe that every woman should have the choice to have sex. If they choose to have sex, I believe that every woman should have the choice to use a condom, or what ever other barrier she can find to protect herself. (No, I do not believe in "the pill" because it can have an abortive effect on the fetus and natural family planning has the same effectiveness if learned correctly by a certified instructor).
 If a woman has unprotected sex - well then she must be choosing to ignore the fact that she could get pregnant, or an STD. For women who have become infected with an STD there is no day after pill that will prevent them from getting cervical cancer or painful warts or losing all ability to reproduce or in the case of AIDS dying (unless they know immediately that the person they slept with has AIDS). Therefore, if the woman chooses to have sex and does not want the baby, she should be happy that she will only have to suffer for nine months and then can give the child to someone else who really wants it.
 That is my pro-choice view. It is also called responsibility for the choices we have made.
 In the case of rape, I can only think of a friend of mine. She was raped at a very young age and became pregnant from it. She chose to keep the baby as a witness to others. Unfortunately, I have lost contact with her, but the last I knew she was a wonderful mother with a beautiful child.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Partial Birth Abortion
